351.10
Taxicab drivers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
767
 
763.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply.
   (a)    "Public vehicles" means all vehicles furnishing individual service as
a business in the transportation of persons which are hereby classified as:
      (1)    Public vehicles which seek their business or a part thereof on the
public streets or quasi-public places such as "taxicabs";
      (2)    Public vehicles which use the public streets for the purpose of
transporting passengers for hire, but which do not seek their business thereon,
or in quasi-public places such as "auto for hire, " "driverless autos for hire"
and "funeral cars”.
Nothing herein shall be construed to apply to vehicles furnishing mass service,
such as motor buses and omnibuses, which move over fixed routes, or on a fixed
schedule or between fixed termini.
   (b)    "Taxicab" means any public vehicle that seeks its business, or a part
thereof on public streets or in quasi-public places.
   (c)    "Funeral car" means any public vehicle that is used solely for
funeral or burial purposes.
   (d)    "Driverless auto for hire" means any public vehicle which is rented
or hired out to a person other than the owner, and operated by the person
renting or hiring the same for his own use and not for the purpose of
transporting persons for compensation.
   (e)    "Auto for hire" means any public vehicle other than funeral car and
driverless auto for hire, that does not seek its business on the public
streets, or in quasipublic places, and which is driven and in charge of the
owner or his employee. Public vehicles used for livery purposes are auto for
hire.
      (Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person operating motor vehicles exclusively within the territorial limits
of the City or within such limits and the territorial limits of municipal
corporations immediately contiguous to the City shall operate a public vehicle
or taxicab, without having obtained a license to do so as provided by this
chapter.
(Ord. 1339-1920. Passed 5-20-29; Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
763.03  VEHICLE LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for licenses of public vehicles shall be made, to the Director
of Public Safety, upon blanks provided by the Director, and shall set forth the
name and address of the applicant, the trade name under which he does business,
the class of each vehicle for which a license is desired, the seating capacity,
the design, color scheme, lettering and marks, if any, to be used on the
vehicle, and any other information required by the Director. If the application
is granted, the applicant shall furnish the Director, prior to the issuance of
the license tags, with information covering the particular vehicle to be
licensed; such information to include the make, the state license number, the
length of time the vehicle has been in use, the motor power thereof, and the
name and address of the person, firm or corporation from which the vehicle was
purchased, and any other information required by the Director, pertinent to the
issuance of a license.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.04  ISSUANCE OF TAXICAB LICENSES.
   The Director of Public Safety shall investigate and hold a hearing as to
each application for license for a taxicab. If the Director finds from such
investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the
operation of the vehicle for which the license is desired, that the vehicle is
a safe and fit conveyance and that it complies with all the requirements of
this chapter, he shall notify the City Auditor, who shall issue a license to
the applicant upon payment of the proper license fee and the furnishing of the
bond or insurance required. If the applicant does not comply with the
requirements of this section within sixty days, the finding of the Director
shall be void.
   If the Director finds from such investigation and hearing that the public
conveyance and necessity do not justify the operation of the vehicle for which
the license is desired, he shall forthwith notify the applicant of his
findings.
   All owners of taxicabs hereby licensed or hereafter granted licenses
according to law, shall, at the completion of the year for which they are
licensed, be entitled to have their licenses renewed for each succeeding year
without a finding of convenience and necessity by the Director, provided all
other requirements of this chapter are complied with.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37; Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
763.05  BOND; SURETIES.
   No person shall receive a license to operate public vehicles until he has
filed with the City Auditor a personal bond with at least two sureties,
approved by the Auditor, a corporate surety bond or policy for insurance from a
responsible company authorized to do business in Ohio, approved by the City
Auditor in such sums as are set out herein, which shall insure the person
operating public vehicles against loss sustained by reason of death of or
injury to persons and for loss for damages to property from the negligence of
such person. If the Auditor finds that any person operating public vehicles has
an excess of assets over liabilities of over one million dollars ($1,000,000),
he shall not require any sureties on a bond filed under the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.06 EXTENT OF LIABILITY. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
763.06 was repealed by Ordinance 95-2002.)
763.07 LIMITATION OF LIABILITY FOR PROPERTY DAMAGE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
763.07 was repealed by Ordinance 95-2002.)
763.08  ADDITIONAL INSURANCE.
   Any insurer limiting his total liability as to property damage in accordance
herewith shall notify the City Auditor forthwith of any insurance payments made
on behalf of the applicant which would operate to reduce the outstanding total
limited liability. The Auditor shall thereupon require adequate additional
insurance and in event of the failure of the applicant to furnish the same on
ten days' notice his license or licenses shall be suspended until the required
additional insurance is provided. Failure to notify the Auditor shall operate
to maintain the total liability of the insurer without allowance for payments
made.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.09  BOND IN LIEU OF INSURANCE.
   In lieu of the policy or policies of insurance herein provided for, the
applicant may furnish a bond executed by a surety company, authorized to do
business in the State, or by two personal sureties, approved as to sufficiency
by the City Auditor and as to legality by the Law Director, holding and binding
the principal and sureties to the same liability, and subject to the same
conditions as in the case of policies or insurance provided for hereunder.
   It shall further be permissible for the applicant to furnish insurance as to
damages for personal injuries, including death and also to cover property
damages or indemnity bond as to cover public liability and property damages or
vice versa.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.10  NOTICE OF TERMINATION OF INSURANCE OR BOND.
   Every policy or certificate of insurance or bond shall contain a clause
obligating the insurer or surety to give the City Auditor at least ten days'
written notice before the cancellation, expiration, lapse or other termination
of such insurance, or the expiration, withdrawal of the surety therefrom or
other termination of the bond. The license granted shall expire upon the
termination of the insurance or bond, or upon the termination of the liability
of the insurer of surety thereon, in accordance with such notice, unless a new
policy or certificate of liability insurance, or a new indemnity bond, approved
as hereinbefore provided, shall be substituted therefor. Failure to give the
notice required shall operate to continue the liability of the insurer or
surety for the benefit of persons injured or damaged, as though the policy
continued in full force and effect.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.11 IDENTIFICATION, PAINTING AND LETTERING OF TAXICABS.
   (a)    Whoever owns and operates a taxicab under license from the City may
adopt any trade name, design, color scheme or method of painting or lettering
of the taxicabs that is approved by the Director of Public Safety. The trade
name, design, color scheme or method of painting or lettering shall include the
following matter:
      (1)    A serial body number assigned by the Director to each taxicab and
painted on each side and on the rear of the taxicab.
      (2)    The name of the owner or the trade name under which he does
business, painted on each side of the taxicab.
   (b)    Whenever the owner's name or the trade name under which he does
business, does not include any one of the words taxicab, taxi, cab or livery,
synonymous with taxicab then the word taxicab shall be painted on each side of
the taxicab immediately beneath the trade name.
   (c)    Whenever any person owning or operating taxicabs does not adopt and
use an approved trade name, design or color scheme or method of painting or
lettering as hereinbefore mentioned, then it shall be mandatory for the person
to paint the following matter on its taxicabs:
      (1)    A framed panel, enclosing on separate lines the name of the owner,
the word taxicab and the serial body number assigned to the taxicab by the
Director. Such panel shall be painted on each side of the taxicab and shall
cover no less area than ten inches by twelve inches. The form of the panel
shall be substantially as follows:
JOHN T. SMITH
TAXICAB
320
      (2)    The serial number assigned the taxicab by the Director shall be
painted on the rear exterior of the taxicab.
   (d)    All mandatory lettering and wording whether in a particular trade
name, design, color scheme, method of painting or lettering or otherwise, as
hereinbefore provided shall be at least two inches in height, and shall be of
such color as in the opinion of the Director will contrast distinctly with the
color of the body of the taxicab.
   The serial body numbers on sides and rear shall be no less than three inches
in height.
   (e)   Whenever the word “paint" or "painted" is used in this chapter, it
means the application of color matter in oil solution, and not in water
solution.
   (f)    No person shall cause or permit any taxicab to appear with a trade
name, design, color scheme or method of painting and lettering that is not
approved by the Director for the vehicle concerned or that is not in accordance
with the terms of this chapter.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.12 RATES OF FARE.
   The rate of fare for use of taxicabs operating under franchise granted by
the City shall be as follows:
 
For the first one-seventh mile        $1.10
For each additional two-sevenths mile 0.30
Waiting time, per hour                6.00
   Provided, that the initial charge or meter trip shall not exceed one dollar
and ten cents ($1.10) and each succeeding charge or meter drop shall not exceed
thirty cents ($0.30).
(Ord. 64-1979. Passed 11-13-79.)
763.13  RATES TO BE FILED WITH DIRECTOR.
   (a)    Every owner of one or more taxicabs shall file in the office of the
Director of Public Safety the complete schedule of rates offered and used.
   (b)    Rate schedules within the purview of Section
763.12 may be changed by the owner. No change in schedule shall become
effective until one day after it is filed with and approved by the Director and
until all requirements have been complied with. Not more than one amended
schedule shall be filed by any owner, in a period of thirty days unless with
the consent of the Director.
   (c)    All schedules of rates of fare on file with the Director shall be
open to public inspection.
   (d)    No person in control of a taxicab shall make any charge except in
accordance with the schedule of rates filed as herein provided.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37; Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
763.14 FARE RECEIPT.
   The driver of a taxicab shall, if requested, deliver to the person paying
for the hire of same at the time of payment, a receipt therefor. Upon this
receipt shall be legibly printed or written the name of the owner and the full
name of the driver, a method of identifying the vehicle or its driver, all
items for which a charge is made, the total amount paid and the date of
payment.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37; Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
763.15 TRANSFER OF OWNERS LICENSE.
   No public vehicle license shall be transferred from one owner to another by
the City Auditor except after a finding of convenience and necessity by the
Director of Public Safety. Such finding shall be arrived at in the same manner
as in the case of an original application. The applicant for the transfer of a
license shall file with his application the consent, in writing, of the former
owner of the license and shall comply with all the terms and conditions of this
chapter governing public vehicles.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.16 TRANSFER OF VEHICLE LICENSE.
   (a)    Should the owner of a licensed vehicle desire to substitute another
vehicle of the same class, the owner shall file an application as provided for
in Section
763.03 hereof, with the Director of Public Safety, setting forth the
information to be furnished as stated in that section. The Director shall
promptly consider the application and if he finds that the applicant is the
owner of the vehicle for which the license is desired, that the vehicle is a
safe and fit conveyance and that it complies with all the requirements of this
chapter, he shall notify the City Auditor who shall transfer the license upon
the furnishing of the bond or insurance required.
 
   (b)    Should the owner of a licensed vehicle desire to substitute
temporarily, not more than thirty days, another vehicle of the same class, the
owner shall file an application as provided in Section
763.03 hereof with the Director setting forth the information to be furnished
as stated in that section. The Director shall promptly consider the
application, and if the Director finds that the applicant is the owner of the
vehicle for which the license is desired, that the vehicle is a safe and fit
conveyance and that it complies with all requirements of this chapter, he shall
notify the Auditor who shall transfer the license to the other vehicle
belonging to the owner for a period of not more than thirty days upon the
furnishing of the bond or insurance required. Within the period of thirty days,
if the owner of the vehicle files an application requesting the transfer of the
license to the vehicle for which it was originally issued, then the Auditor
shall transfer the license, if the condition of the vehicle shall be
satisfactory to the Director under the terms and conditions of this chapter.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.17  TAXICAB STANDS AND PARKING .
   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to establish taxicab stands as
will serve the best interests of the public. The stands shall be reserved
exclusively for the parking of taxicabs while awaiting passengers for hire. No
taxicab shall park continuously in a taxicab stand for a period exceeding one
hour. It shall be the duty of the Director to designate taxicab stands by
stanchions or signs indicating that they are taxicab stands. The Director shall
have continuing authority to establish, enlarge, diminish or discontinue any
taxicab stands. No person shall park any vehicle other than a taxicab in a
taxicab stand. (Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.18 VEHICLE LICENSE FEES.
   No public vehicle shall be operated without a license. License fees for each
public vehicle shall be payable to the City Treasurer in the following amounts
per annum:
 
Taxicab                                 $30.00
Driverless Autos for hire (rental cars) No fee
Autos for Hire (limousine services)     No fee
Funeral Cars                            No fee
Truck                                   No fee
(Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
763.19 LICENSE TERM.
   The license shall be dated January 1, of each year, and shall expire on
December 31 of the year in which it is issued. However, if a license after July
1 of any license year, only one half of the yearly license fee for such public
vehicle shall be charged.
   The license fee in Section
763.18 or as prorated in this section shall be in addition to the fee required
under the laws of the State of Ohio on all motor vehicles.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.20 METAL TAG; DISPLAY.
   At the time the license is issued by the City Auditor to the owner of any
public vehicle, the Auditor shall also issue to the owner a metal tag showing
the class of public vehicle, the license number and the year for which it is
issued. The tags for each class of public vehicle shall be numbered
consecutively each year, and the numbers on the tags shall correspond with the
license numbers. No tag shall be displayed on any public vehicle except the one
for which it is issued. The tag shall be affixed to the front of the vehicle so
as to be plainly discernible at all times.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.21 TRANSFER OF TAG.
   No tag shall be issued or displayed on any public vehicle except the public
vehicle for which it is issued. The Director of Public Safety may, upon the
sale of any licensed public vehicle, authorize the Auditor to transfer the
license for such public vehicle to the purchaser thereof complying with the
terms and conditions of this chapter governing public vehicles. If any licensed
owner of a public vehicle has lost the tag as herein described or if the tag
has been stolen from him, a new tag shall be delivered to the licensed owner
upon notification by the Director that the licensed owner has filed with the
Director a sworn statement containing the facts covering such loss or theft,
and upon payment of the cost of the tag.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
763.22 GARAGE RECORD OF HIRED AUTOS AND TAXIS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
763.22 was repealed by Ordinance 95-2002.)
763.23 PASSENGER CARRYING FOR HIRE BY OTHER VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   The carrying of passengers as a business for compensation by any vehicle
that does not comply with the provisions of this chapter is hereby prohibited.
Public vehicles that are not permitted to carry passengers as a business under
this chapter may bring passengers into the City, but may not pick up any
passengers for any destination or accept any business within the City.
(Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
763.24 DIRECTOR'S AUTHORITY GOVERNING PUBLIC VEHICLES.
   It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Safety to study the
transportation problem of the City, to investigate all complaints and make
recommendations looking to the betterment of transportation conditions of the
City, and to make rules and regulations governing the operation of public
vehicles.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
   The Director is empowered to establish and adopt the rules and regulations
governing the issuance of public vehicle licenses, the inspection of public
vehicles and their appurtenances as are reasonable and necessary and not
inconsistent with the terms of this chapter.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37. )
763.25 REVOCATION OF LICENSE FOR MISREPRESENTATION.
   Whenever it appears upon investigation and hearing by the Director of Public
Safety that a license issued hereunder has been obtained by misrepresentation,
the Director shall notify the City Auditor of such fact and the Auditor shall
thereupon revoke or suspend the license.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.26  APPEAL.
   (a)    Any act, order, rule, regulation or decision of the Director of
Public Safety shall be subject to appeal to Council by the person aggrieved
provided that the appeal is filed with the Clerk of Council within ten days
after the promulgation of the act, order, rule, regulation or decision.
(Ord. 1339-1929. Passed 5-20-29.)
   (b)    Whenever the Director has refused to authorize a public vehicle
license or approve a change in rate schedule, or whenever the City Auditor has
suspended or revoked a public vehicle license, the applicant within ten days
after receiving notice of the denial, approval, suspension or revocation, may
appeal to Council. Council may either consider the appeal on the evidence
produced before the Director, or permit the introduction of new evidence,
inspection and tests. The decision of Council shall be final.
(Ord. 10-1937. Passed 4-19-37.)
763.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   General: Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no
other penalty is specified, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (b)   Failure to pay fare: Whoever, with intent to defraud the owner or
driver of any public vehicle, engages carriage therein, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
   (c)   Operation without license: Whoever operates or permits to be operated
for hire, a public vehicle not licensed in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter or any ordinance of the City, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree. In the event of conviction, the person not thereafter be
permitted to operate a public vehicle within the City for a period of five
years from the date of such conviction.
   (d)   Immoral use of vehicle: Whoever uses a public vehicle for any unlawful
or immoral purpose shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Upon
information from the Director of Public Safety that such unlawful or immoral
use has occurred with knowledge of the person owning the public vehicle, the
City Auditor shall revoke the vehicle license for the vehicle involved.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 767
Taxicab Drivers
767.01   Definitions.
767.02   License required.
767.03   Application; procedure.
767.04   License fees.
767.05   Examination of knowledge and skill of applicant.
767.06   Issuance; denial of license.
767.07   Reapplication after denial.
767.08   Driver’s badge.
767.09   Replacement of lost badge.
767.10   Identification card.
767.11   Renewal of license.
767.12   Return of badge.
767.13   Solicitation of passengers prohibited.
767.14   Smoking prohibited.
767.15   Unauthorized persons in public vehicles.
767.16   Driver to remain with vehicle.
767.17   Change of address.
767.18   Revocation of license.
767.19   Additional rules and regulations.
767.20   General authority of Director to revoke.
767.21   Notice of suspension or revocation.
767.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Motor vehicle operator's license - see TRAF. Ch.
335
Taxicabs - see BUS. REG. Ch.
763
 
767.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Director" means the Director of Public Safety.
   (b)    "Drivers license" means the license required under this chapter to
operate taxicabs and autos for hire.
   (c)    "Taxicab" or "auto for hire" means any taxicab or auto for hire
licensed or required to be licensed by the City.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53. )
767.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall drive a taxicab or auto for hire unless duly licensed as
hereinafter provided. (Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.03 APPLICATION; PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Every applicant for a license as a driver of a taxicab or auto for
hire shall make
application to the Director of Public Safety on forms to be supplied by the
Director. The application shall set forth that the applicant is:
      (1)   A citizen of the United States;
      (2)   Able to speak, read and write English;
      (3)   Eighteen years of age or over;
      (4)   Free of defective vision, defective hearing, epilepsy, vertigo,
heart trouble and any other infirmity, physical or mental, which would render
him unfit for safe operation of a public vehicle;
      (5)   Not addicted to the use of alcohol or drugs and such other
pertinent information as the Director may require.
   (b)   Applications shall be sworn to by the applicant.
   (c)   The application form shall further contain the certificate of a
reputable physician of the City stating that the applicant is free from
infirmities which would prevent his driving a public conveyance with safety.
   (d)   The applicant shall file with his application two photographs of
himself of a size designated by the Director, which photographs shall have been
taken within thirty days next preceding the date of the application. (A.O.)
   (e)   The applications will contain a release permitting the Director of
Public Safety or his employees or agents to check the applicant’s traffic and
criminal records with any Clerk of Courts or Bureau of Motor Vehicles. The
applicant shall file with his application a photocopy of his driver’s license.
(Ord. 22-1996. Passed 4-23-96.)
767.04 LICENSE FEES.
   Every driver of a taxicab or auto for hire shall pay to the City Auditor a
license fee of six dollars ($6.00) per annum for an original license and four
dollars ($4.00) per annum for each renewal.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53; Ord. 95-1966. Passed 12-30-66; Ord. 46-1980.
Passed 10-14-80.)
767.05 EXAMINATION OF KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL OF APPLICANT.
   After complying with the provisions of Section
767.03, every applicant shall be examined by the Director of Public Safety or
an inspector or deputy under his direction as to his knowledge of the
provisions governing the operation of taxicabs and autos for hire, and as to
his knowledge of the City and the traffic regulations. The applicant shall
produce evidence that he has had at least six months experience in operating a
motor vehicle and shall, if required, demonstrate his ability. Any taxicab
driver who submits a current license from the City of Cincinnati shall be
exempted from undergoing an independent examination.
(Ord. 94-2002. Passed 12-30-02.)
767.06 ISSUANCE; DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   (a)   If the Director of Public Safety is satisfied that the applicant is
suitable and proper person to drive a taxicab or auto for hire, he shall notify
the City Auditor in writing and the Auditor shall issue a license to the
applicant upon payment of the proper fee. The decision of the Director shall be
final.
   (b)   An applicant’s conviction of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving
moral turpitude may be sufficient grounds for the Safety Director to find that
the applicant is not a suitable and proper person to drive a taxicab or auto
for hire.
(Ord. 23-1996. Passed 4-23-96.)
   
767.07 REAPPLICATION AFTER DENIAL.
   When an applicant has been denied a driver's license, no new application
shall be considered for a period of three months.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53. )
767.08  DRIVER'S BADGE.
   At the time a driver's license is issued, the City Auditor shall issue to
the driver a badge, the size and design of which shall be determined by the
Auditor, upon which badge shall be inscribed or imprinted the word "chauffeur",
together with the number of the license and the year in which it was issued.
The badges shall be numbered consecutively and the number thereon shall
correspond with the number of the license issued to the driver. Whenever a
driver is driving any vehicle for which a driver's license is required, he
shall wear his badge conspicuously and constantly upon such part of his cap or
outer garments as shall be designated by the Director of Public Safety. Such
badge and license shall not be assigned or transferred to any other person.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.09 REPLACEMENT OF LOST BADGE.
   In case of the loss of a badge, the driver may file with the Director of
Public Safety a sworn statement containing the facts of such loss. The Director
shall thereupon notify the City Auditor, who shall deliver a new badge to the
driver upon payment of one dollar ($1.00) for the first replacement and of two
dollars ($2.00) for each replacement thereafter.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.10 IDENTIFICATION CARD.
   At the time of the issuance of a driver's license, the City Auditor shall
also issue an identification card, upon which shall be affixed one of the
photographs filed with the Director of Public Safety. The identification card
shall be displayed at all times by the licensee when he is driving a taxicab or
auto for hire.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.11 RENEWAL OF LICENSE.
   Driver's licenses as provided in this chapter shall expire on March 31 in
each year. Licenses must be renewed within thirty days after expiration,
otherwise application must be made for a new license as provided for original
applicants. Applications for renewals shall be made to the Director of Public
Safety who may authorize renewal of licenses without further examination. The
City Auditor shall issue renewals only upon receipt of notice from the
Director.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.12 RETURN OF BADGE.
   Upon renewal of any driver's license such driver shall return to the City
Auditor all badges theretofore issued to him. In the event such badges have
been lost, the applicant shall file an affidavit to that effect with the
Director of Public Safety. (Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.13  SOLICITATION OF PASSENGERS PROHIBITED.
   No driver of a taxicab shall solicit passengers on public streets or in
quasi-public places either by motion of hand or by word of mouth. The driver of
an auto for hire shall neither solicit nor accept passengers in any manner on
public streets or in quasi-public places.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.14 SMOKING PROHIBITED.
   Drivers of taxicabs or autos for hire are prohibited from smoking while
carrying passengers.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.15  UNAUTHORIZED PERSON IN PUBLIC VEHICLES.
   Whenever any taxicab or auto for hire is occupied by a fare-paying passenger
or passengers, or by members of the party of a fare-paying passenger, the
driver of such taxicab or auto for hire shall permit no other person to occupy
or ride in the same.
   Whenever any taxicab is unoccupied or not completely occupied but is seeking
business, the driver of such taxicab shall permit no person not intending to
pay a fare to occupy or ride in the same.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.16 DRIVER TO REMAIN WITH VEHICLE.
   The driver of any taxicab shall remain in or beside his vehicle at all times
when such vehicle is standing upon the public streets, except when such vehicle
is parked or standing in a designated taxicab stand.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.17 CHANGE OF ADDRESS.
   Every licensed driver shall have his residence address on file with the
Director of Public Safety and in case of change, shall notify the Director in
writing immediately.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.18 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)    Defacing certificate.  No licensed driver shall deface any license,
certificate, badge, tag, identification card or rate card or remove, tamper
with or alter a rate card displayed in a public vehicle. In case of any
violation of this subsection the City Auditor shall, on notification by the
Director of Public Safety revoke the driver's license. Such revocation shall be
in addition to any other penalty imposed.
   (b)    Driving while intoxicated. Conviction of driving while intoxicated
shall operate as a revocation of any driver's license issued hereunder and such
driver shall not be eligible to receive a new license for a period of one year
from the date of such conviction.
   (c)    Driving while Suspended. Whenever a licensed driver is convicted for
driving a vehicle for which a driver's license is required during a period for
which his license has been suspended, it shall be mandatory upon the Director
to notify the Auditor, who shall revoke the license of such driver, and such
driver shall not be eligible to receive a new license for a period of one year
from the date of the revocation.
   (d)    Other Causes. The Auditor shall revoke the license of any licensed
driver whenever the Director shall recommend revocation for any of the
following reasons:
      (1)    Licensee having obtained a license by false statements in his
application, upon misrepresentation or upon false statements on his affidavits
in applying for a duplicate badge.
      (2)    Licensee having become physically or mentally incapable of driving
a vehicle.
      (3)    Licensee having been convicted of a felony.
      (4)    Licensee having been convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.19  ADDITIONAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Safety is hereby authorized to establish and adopt
such additional rules and regulations governing the issuance of licenses to
drive taxicabs or autos for hire as may be reasonable and necessary and not
inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.20 GENERAL AUTHORITY OF DIRECTOR TO REVOKE.
   The Director of Public Safety shall have continuing jurisdiction as to
licenses granted hereunder. In the event of misconduct or acts on the part of a
licensed driver which show him to be an unsuitable person to drive a public
vehicle or which would be sufficient to justify the refusal of a license in the
case of an original applicant, the Director may notify the City Auditor, who
shall revoke a license already granted.
(Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.21 NOTICE OF SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   The City Auditor shall notify the driver of any suspension or revocation of
his license and shall require such driver to turn in his certificate, license,
badge and identification card. Such notification shall be by registered mail,
directed to the last address of the driver on file with the Director of Public
Safety. (Ord. 9-1953. Passed 2-10-53.)
767.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which no other penalty
is specified, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   For the habitual violation of the provisions of this chapter the City
Auditor, upon recommendation of the Director of Public Safety shall revoke the
driver’s license.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 771
Video Service Providers
771.01   Definitions.
771.02   Fee.
771.03   PEG access payment.
771.04   Notice of fee.
771.05   PEG channels requirement.
771.06   PEG channel programming.
771.07   Quarterly payment of fee.
771.08   Notice to City.
771.09   Incumbent cable providers.
 
771.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following definitions apply to the terms used herein:
   (a)   “Incumbent Cable Provider” means any person who on the effective date
of this ordinance is the holder of a cable franchise agreement with the City as
granted pursuant to 47 U.S.C. 541.
   (b)   “PEG” means the activities or actions performed for the benefit of
public, educational, and government video programming by the City.
   (c)   “Video Service” means the service defined in Ohio R.C. 1332.21(J).
   (d)   “Video Service Authorization or VSA” means the authorization granted
to a video service provider in accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C.
1332.21 to 1332.34 et seq.
   (e)   “Video Service Provider Fee or VSP Fee” means the fee paid by a VSP in
accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 1332.32.
   (f)   “Video Service Provider or VSP” means a person, firm, or corporation
granted a video service authorization under Ohio R.C. Sections 1332.21 to
1332.334 et seq.
      (Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.02  FEE.
   In accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 1332.32 all VSPs providing
video service in the City pursuant to a VSA obtained from the Director of the
Ohio Department of Commerce shall pay a VSP fee in the amount of five percent
(5%) of gross revenues received from providing Video Service in the City, which
gross revenue base shall include advertising received revenues. The VSP fee
shall be paid quarterly, not later than sixty (60) days after the end of each
quarter.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.03 PEG ACCESS PAYMENT.
   The VSP shall be responsible for a pro rata share of the PEG Access Payment
that the incumbent VSP provides to the City of Norwood pursuant to Exhibit B of
the Cable Franchise Agreement. A VSP’s pro rata share of the PEG Access Payment
shall be based on its proportion of video service subscribers with service
addresses in the City. For the purpose of determining the pro rata shares, all
VSPs shall report quarterly to the City the total number of subscribers served
within the City. This information shall be treated as confidential by the City
and shall only be used to derive the pro rata shares. The VSP shall remit its
pro rata share to the City via any appropriate negotiable instrument payable to
City of Norwood, 4645 Montgomery Road, Cincinnati, Ohio 45212 not sooner than
forty-five nor later than sixty days after the preceding calendar quarter.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.04 NOTICE OF FEE.
   Upon receipt of notice from a VSP that it will begin providing Video Service
in the City pursuant to a state-issued video service authorization, the Safety-
Service Director or his or her designee is authorized and directed to provide
such VSP with notice of the VSP fee as determined by this chapter which notice
shall be delivered in a manner that provides for proof of timely delivery.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.05 PEG CHANNELS REQUIREMENT.
   Upon receipt of notice from a VSP that it will begin providing Video Service
in the City pursuant to a VSA, the Safety Service Director or his or her
designee is authorized and directed to provide such VSP with notice that the
VSP shall be required to provide the same number of PEG channels in the City
under the same service tier conditions and subject to the same channel
reclamation conditions as may be proscribed by the Ohio R.C. 1332.30(A)(1)(a-b)
for the Incumbent Cable Provider with the most recent obligation in the City,
which notice shall be delivered in a manner that provides for proof of timely
delivery and shall state the appropriate number of PEG channels and service
tiers required to be provided by the VSP within the City within one-hundred and
twenty (120) days after delivery of such notice.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.06 PEG CHANNEL PROGRAMMING.
   In accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 1332.30(A)(1)(a) when more
than three (3) PEG access channels are provided to the City by an Incumbent
Cable Provider or VSP, such additional channel shall be programmed by the City
with at least forty (40) hours of non-character generated content per week with
at least sixty percent (60%) of the programming being non-repeat and locally
produced. For the purposes of this section “non-repeat and locally produced”
shall mean, the first three (3) playbacks of programming produced or provided
by any local resident, the City or its affiliates, or any local public or
private agency that provides services to the Greater Cincinnati metro area, or
any transmission of a meeting or proceeding of any local, state, or federal
government entity.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.07 QUARTERLY PAYMENT OF FEE.
   Any VSP fee to be paid to the City by a VSP shall be made quarterly and be
remitted directly to the City via any appropriate negotiable instrument payable
to City of Norwood, 4645 Montgomery Road, Cincinnati, Ohio 45212 not later than
sixty days after the end of each calendar quarter. (Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-
09.)
771.08  NOTICE TO CITY.
   Any notice to the City that is required of a VSP in accordance with Ohio
R.C. 1332.21 through 1332.34 shall be provided in written form to the Safety-
Service Director either by certified mail, express mail, or personal delivery,
all evidenced by a return receipt.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)
771.09 INCUMBENT CABLE PROVIDERS.
   The additional requirements to VSPs enacted in this chapter shall not apply
to Incumbent Cable Providers. The relationship between the City and such
providers shall be governed by the franchise agreement between the parties
until its expiration or until the Incumbent Cable Provider is granted a VSA in
accordance with Ohio Revised Code Section 1332.21-1331.34 et seq.
(Ord. 17-2009. Passed 3-24-09.)

905.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall make any excavations in the surface or pavement of any
street, alley, sidewalk or public way of the City, unless a permit to make the
excavation has been issued in accordance with the regulations contained in this
chapter.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.02 APPLICATION; DEPOSIT; ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Whoever desires to make any excavation in any surface or pavement of
any street, alley, sidewalk or public way of the City, shall file with the
Director of Public Service, on a blank provided therefor, an application for a
permit which application shall state the name of the applicant, the name of the
street, alley, sidewalk or public way of the City, the kind of pavement
thereon, the purpose of the proposed excavation, and the exact size and
location of the proposed excavation, when in the opinion of the Director, the
giving of the exact size and location is practicable.
   (b)   No permit shall be issued in response to this application until a
deposit of money is made with the City Treasurer in the amount as may be deemed
by the Director to be amply sufficient to cover the cost of restoring the
street surface or pavement; these deposits to be credited to the Street
Restoration Fund. This cost shall be determined according to rules to be
prescribed by the Director, and shall be estimated at a certain price per
square yard for each kind of street pavement.
   (c)   Upon the filing of the above application and the presentation of the
receipt of the Treasurer that sufficient funds are on deposit to cover the
estimated cost of restoring the street, alley, sidewalk or public way, as above
specified, the Director may issue a permit to make the excavation described in
the application; the permit to state the name of the applicant, the name of the
street, alley, sidewalk or public way, the kind of pavement thereon, the
purpose of the proposed excavation, and the exact size and location of the
proposed excavation, when in the opinion of the Director the giving of the
exact size and location is practicable. Where, however, the nature of the
proposed work is such as to require a series of excavations, and where, in the
opinion of the Director, it is impossible or impracticable to determine in
advance the exact size and location of contemplated excavations, a permit may
be issued covering the series of excavations for the street, alley, sidewalk or
public way, as may be deemed proper by the Director.
   (d)   In case the applicant desires to excavate more street area than
originally applied for, an additional deposit sufficient to cover costs of
restoring the additional areas shall be paid to the Treasurer. The Director or
his chief engineer is hereby authorized to immediately stop the work until such
increased deposit of money is made.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.03 EXCAVATIONS LIMITED.
   (a)   No person shall make any opening in, break, tear up, excavate or
remove the surface of any street, avenue, alley or other public way, or any
portion thereof, in the City, in, on or upon any street, avenue, alley or other
public way, which shall be built, paved, resurfaced or repaved with any
material other than water bound macadam at any time within a period of five
years after the building, paving resurfacing or repaving of the street or
alley. The Director of Public Service and all other officers and departments of
the City are hereby prohibited from granting any permits for any such openings,
breaks, tearing up, excavation or removal within this period.
   (b)   However, the Director may, on account of any emergency affecting
public health or public welfare, and which could not have been foreseen,
suspend the operation of this five year rule as to any application for a
permit, and in such cases, upon granting of the application, the work may be
performed within the five year period; but the mere failure or neglect of the
applicant, or other person, firm or corporation to lay or have laid mains,
pipes, wires or connections or other means of transportation of utilities
before the five year period, or the inconvenience, by reason of the failure or
neglect, to property along the particular street or way described in the
application shall not be considered to be an emergency.
 
   (c)   Where water mains or water pipes were laid along or to any lot or
piece of property
previous to the beginning of the five year period, and, by reason of unforseen
development, the water mains or service pipes have become, in the opinion of
the Director, of inadequate size, then the Director may suspend the five year
rule for the purpose of and to the extent necessary for the laying of larger
water mains or larger service pipes in any street or other public way. The five
year period shall be deemed to begin at the time of the completion and final
acceptance by the City of any construction, paving, resurfacing or repaving.
   (d)    The provisions of this section and Sections
905.04 to
905.06 shall apply to all streets, avenues, alleys or other public ways, or any
portion thereof, as described in this section but shall not include sidewalks .
(Ord. 325 -1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.04 NOTICE TO PROPERTY OWNERS.
   Each notice now required by State Law to be given to the owner of each piece
of property to be assessed, of the passage of the resolution by Council
declaring the necessity for constructing, paving or resurfacing any street or
alley, or other public way, shall contain, in addition to the other
requirements of the law, a notice to the property owner that any excavation
within the limits of the street, public way or alley, for the purpose of laying
gas or water mains or of making water, gas or sewer connections, or for any
other purpose, must be made before the beginning of such work of construction,
paving or resurfacing.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.05 NOTICE TO UTILITY COMPANIES.
   At the time the notice is sent to or served upon the abutting property
holders, it shall also be the duty of the Clerk of Council to send, by mail, a
copy of the notice to each person, firm or corporation that at that time is
engaged in the business of furnishing light, heat, gas, electricity, power,
telephone or telegraph service or other public utilities requiring the
occupancy of any part of the streets, public ways or alleys of the City.
Failure of the Clerk to send, or of such property owners or corporations or
officers to receive such notices shall not in any way affect the other
regulations of this chapter, or the penalties hereby imposed, and shall not be
deemed to create an emergency within the meaning of Section
905.03.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.06 TEMPORARY SUSPENSION OF WORK; NOTICE TO RESUME.
   In any case when the construction, paving or repaving of any street, public
way or alley necessitates a cut or fill of such depth as to make it
impracticable to lay mains or to make connections prior to the grading of the
street, alley or way, then in such cases the Director of Public Service may
suspend the work upon the street, alley or way when the same has been brought
to a convenient grade for the laying of mains, pipes and making sewer, light
and other connections, for a reasonable length of time, to give the property
owners and persons and corporations engaged in business necessitating the use
or occupancy of any part of the street, alley or way, a reasonable opportunity
for the laying of the mains, pipes or conduits and the making of the
connections. The Director shall order the work of construction, paving or
resurfacing to be resumed after the lapse of such reasonable length of time and
notice shall be given by the Director to the property owners abutting upon the
cut or fill and to the other persons or corporations interested, as
hereinbefore enumerated, notifying them of the date upon which the work of
construction, paving or resurfacing will be resumed. The failure to give or
receive the notice shall not affect the other provisions of this chapter or the
penalties hereby imposed, and shall not be deemed to create an emergency within
the meaning of Section
905.03.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.07 RESTORATION WORK; INSPECTION.
   The work of or connected with the restoring of the surface or pavement of
the street, alley, sidewalk or public way, and back filling, shall be done by
or under the supervision and control of the Department of Public Service. The
above work of restoration and backfilling shall be completed in accordance with
the specifications on file with the Director of Public Service. An inspector
may be assigned to see that the specifications are followed. The expense of
this inspection shall be part of the cost of restoring the excavation, if it be
deemed necessary or expedient by the Director.
905.08 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICE; DUTIES.
   The Director of Public Service is hereby directed to prepare and to keep on
hand suitable application and permit forms as provided by this chapter, and to
adopt and enforce suitable rules and regulations for determining the estimated
cost of the restoration of any excavations in any street, alley, sidewalk or
public way and for the restoration by the Department of Public Works of the
excavations. The Director is also to employ any clerks, inspectors, and other
employees as may be deemed necessary to carry into effect the provisions of
this chapter, and the salaries of the clerks, inspectors and other employees
shall be paid by the City Treasurer out of Street Restoration Fund on
presentation of the proper voucher or payroll, signed according to law.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.09 EMERGENCY EXCAVATION; PERMIT.
   No annual, emergency or blanket permit shall be granted by the Director of
Public Service. In unforseen emergencies, when the necessities of the public
require, any person, firm or corporation shall be allowed to make the
excavation; provided, that in such case an application for permit shall be made
by the person, firm or corporation within two hours after the excavation has
been made. In case the office of the Director is closed, an application for
permit shall be made not later than 10:00 a.m. the following day.
(Ord. 325-1917. Passed 7-16-17.)
905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for each separate offense. Excavation made in violation of any
provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 909
Sidewalks, Driveways and Gutters
909.01   Supervision; specifications.
909.02   Grade stakes.
909.03   Application; permit.
909.04   License required.
909.05   Certificate of acceptance; bond; license fees.
909.06   Duty to keep and maintain gutters.
909.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Notice to construct or repair sidewalks - see Ohio R. C. 729.03 et seq.
Sidewalk obstructions, damage or injury - see GEN. OFF.
521.04
Excavations - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
905
Duty to clean, repair sidewalks, gutters - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
 
909.01  SUPERVISION; SPECIFICATIONS.
   The Director of Public Service shall supervise the construction of all
sidewalks and driveways within the City limits. He shall cause specifications
to be prepared and kept on file in his office.
(Ord. 388-1918. Passed 5-6-18.)
909.02 GRADE STAKES.
   Whoever constructs or repairs a sidewalk or driveway shall cause the same to
be done in accordance with the established grade and the specifications
provided under Section
909.01 and under the direction of the City Engineer, who shall give such grade
stakes and information as may be necessary for a strict compliance with the
provisions hereof.
(Ord. 388-1918. Passed 5-6-18. )
909.03 APPLICATION; PERMIT.
   (a)    No person shall hereafter construct or lay a sidewalk or construct or
lay a driveway across a sidewalk or from a public street into private property,
either of cement or other material on any public street in the City, without
first securing a permit.
   The application for permit shall contain a statement showing the location of
such proposed sidewalk or driveway and the name and address of the owner of the
premises.
(Ord. 388-1918. Passed 5-6-18. )
   (b)    The permit to construct a driveway from a public street into private
property shall not be issued where the purpose of the permit is to establish a
place to park a vehicle, automobile or truck, unless a hardtop surfaced drive
is to be constructed into the place upon which the vehicle, automobile or truck
is to be moved or parked.
(Ord. 52-1962. Passed 11-13-62.)
909.04 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No permit shall be granted to construct, lay or repair a sidewalk or
construct, lay or repair a driveway across the sidewalk until such person has
first secured a license as a contractor, which license shall be dated on June
1, and shall be renewed annually.
(Ord. 388-1918. Passed 5-6-18.)
909.05 CERTIFICATE OF ACCEPTANCE; BOND; LICENSE FEES.
   (a)    The Director of Public Service upon being satisfied that such person
is qualified to properly construct and lay sidewalks or driveways shall, on
application made to him, issue a certificate of such fact to the City Auditor.
(Ord. 388-1918. Passed 5-6-18.)
   (b)    Such person shall give bond or deposit a certified check with the
City Treasurer in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) conditioned to at
once relay any such sidewalk or driveway if improperly laid upon determination
by inspection by the City. Any contractor shall have the right of appeal to
Council upon the adverse decision by any inspector of the City upon timely
appeal filed with the Clerk of Council. All appeals shall be filed within ten
days of mailing of such notice of adverse decision by the City or its agent.
Appeal from any decision by Council shall be as provided by Ohio R.C. 2506.01
et seq. Upon receipt of such certificate from the Director of Public Service,
written notice from the Treasurer that a certified check payable to the City
has been deposited or bond filed with the City Auditor, the City Auditor shall
issue a license authorizing the applicant to engage in the above described work
and the Auditor shall charge a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for such
license for the first year and fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each yearly
renewal.
   (c)    Any individual, corporation, partnership or proprietorship upon
notice of adverse inspection by the City of any work performed shall not be
issued additional permits until deposit of additional bond or certified check
payable to the City in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is
deposited with the City Treasurer.
   (d)    Adverse decision shall mean any decision by the inspector of the City
or its agent that a sidewalk or driveway shall be relayed. (Ord. 34-1992.
Passed 12-22-92.)
909.06 DUTY TO KEEP AND MAINTAIN GUTTERS.
   No person shall obstruct any gutter or drain or permit the same to become
obstructed or become foul in front of or abutting upon the premises owned or
occupied by him during the construction, reconstruction or repair of a building
or at any other time and it shall be the duty of any person, firm or
corporation to keep and maintain the gutters abutting upon the premises owned
or occupied by him clear and clean. (Ord. 1719-1904. Passed 12-5-04.)
909.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for each separate offense.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 913
Trees
913.01   Planting regulations.
913.02   Trees and shrubbery on private property: trimming; removal and
assessment by Municipality.
913.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R. C. 715.20
Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R. C. 727.011
Injury or destruction - see GEN. OFF.
541.06
 
913.01 PLANTING REGULATIONS.
   No person shall plant or transplant any trees in the public right of way of
the City unless approved by the Director of Public Service.
913.02 TREES AND SHRUBBERY ON PRIVATE PROPERTY: TRIMMING; REMOVAL AND
ASSESSMENT BY MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)    The owner of every lot or parcel of land within the corporate limits
upon which a tree, plant or shrubbery stands with any part thereof upon or
overhanging a public street or sidewalk shall conform to the regulations
provided in this section; otherwise, the person shall be subject to penalty
provided in Section
913.99, and the Municipality shall cause such tree, plant or shrubbery to be
trimmed or cut down and removed in accordance with the procedure established by
subsection (b) hereof and assess the cost thereof against the owner of such lot
or parcel of land.
      (1)    The owner shall trim or cause to be trimmed any tree, plant or
shrubbery so that a clear height of eight feet between the lowest branch of the
same and the sidewalk or the street is maintained.
      (2)    The owner shall trim or remove, as the case may require, every
dead, decayed or broken tree, plant or shrubbery, or part thereof, so that the
same shall not fall to the street or sidewalk.
      (3)    The owner shall cut down and remove any tree, plant or shrubbery,
or any part thereof, as may be necessary to provide a clear and unobstructed
view of traffic from all directions at any street intersection, or abate any
nuisance necessary to protect life, limb or property of persons, drivers of
vehicles or pedestrians using the street or sidewalk.
   (b)    In the event the provisions of subsection (a) hereof are not complied
with, the Director of Public Service shall cause to be trimmed or removed such
tree, plant or shrubbery or part thereof.
   (c)    Whenever any tree, plant or shrubbery, or part thereof, is trimmed or
removed by the Municipality in accordance with subsection (b) hereof, the
Municipality shall give five days notice, by certified mail with return
receipt, to the owner of such lot or parcel of land at his last known address,
to pay the cost of such trimming or removal. The notice shall be accompanied by
a statement of the amount of cost incurred. In the event the same is not paid
within thirty days after the mailing of the notice, the amount shall be
certified by the City Auditor to the County Auditor for collection the same as
other taxes and assessments are collected.
913.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for each separate offense.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 917
Special Street Privileges
917.01   Definitions.
917.02   Building encroachment.
917.03   Permittee.
917.04   Privileged premises.
917.05   Special street privilege.
917.06   Special street privileges, general.
917.07   Building encroachments, regulation.
917.08   Special street privileges, regulation.
917.09   Use for advertising purposes prohibited.
917.10   Changes in street uses.
917.11   Street restoration.
917.12   Termination of special street privilege.
917.13   Liability of permittee.
917.14   Revocability.
917.15   Notice.
917.16   Unlawful private use of streets.
917.17   Secret street uses.
917.18   Discovery of unlawful uses.
917.19   Control by Building Commissioner or Service Director.
917.20   Fences.
917.21   Water meters and pits.
917.22   Penalties.
917.23   Violation of Section
917.16.
917.24   Violation of Section
917.17.
917.25   Portable storage container.
 
917.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the words and phrases defined in the
sections hereunder shall have the meanings therein respectively ascribed to
them, unless a different meaning is clearly indicated by the context.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.02 BUILDING ENCROACHMENT.
   "Building encroachment" shall mean the occupancy of a public street, alley
or way, on, under or above the street surface, by a construction constituting a
part of a building such as a vault, balcony, bay-window, marquee, sign or other
construction.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.03 PERMITTEE.
   "Permittee" shall mean a person, firm or corporation in possession of a
special street privilege. Where the privilege granted is directly appurtenant
to the abutting real estate, "permittee" shall mean the owner of such real
estate.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.04 PRIVILEGED PREMISES.
   "Privileged premises" shall mean the lot or parcel of real estate to which a
special street privilege is appurtenant.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.05 SPECIAL STREET PRIVILEGE.
   "Special street privilege" shall mean any private right authorized by a
specific ordinance for the use of a part of a City street, alley or way,
separate and distinct from the use of city streets, alleys and way by the
general public or by authorized public utility corporations.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.06 SPECIAL STREET PRIVILEGES, GENERAL.
   The enjoyment of special privileges on, under or over public streets, alleys
and ways by abutting owners or others for private purposes shall be subject to
regulation and control as provided in this chapter. Nothing in this chapter
shall apply to the use of city streets by duly authorized public utility
corporations for the furnishing of utility services to consumers in the City of
Norwood in accordance with regulations established by ordinance.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.07 BUILDING ENCROACHMENTS, REGULATION.
   Unless otherwise specially permitted, encroachments by building structures
on public streets, alleys or way shall be regulated in accordance with the
provisions of the Building Code of the City of Norwood.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.08 SPECIAL STREET PRIVILEGES, REGULATION.
   Special street privileges shall be exercised in accordance with a specific
ordinance of Council defining the terms and conditions of the use(s) permitted.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.09 USE FOR ADVERTISING PURPOSES PROHIBITED.
   No bridge or other private structure permitted to be erected across a City
street, alley or way in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be
used for business signs or other commercial advertising purposes except as may
be permitted by specific ordinance authorizing a revocable street privilege.
Whenever any permittee shall be found to have used a special street privilege
contrary to this provision, a charge shall be imposed for the commercial value
of such use, in no event less than ten dollars ($10.00) per day. Nothing herein
shall prevent prosecution of the permittee in accordance with Section
917.22, herein.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.10 CHANGES IN STREET USES.
   (a)   The permittee of any special street privilege may be required at any
time on 30 days notice by the City to make any necessary change in the
construction or location of a permitted use which may be required in connection
with street widening or other change of street uses by the City, or in
connection with the authorized location or change of location of public utility
service lines, pipes, poles or other equipment.
   (b)   If the permittee shall fail to make the required change in accordance
with the order of the City, the City shall have the authority to make the
change and charge the cost to the permittee or, in the case of privately owned
public utility company, the City shall authorize such company to make the
change and the permittee shall be liable for the reasonable cost thereof.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.11 STREET RESTORATION.
   (a)   The cost of all street restoration and sidewalk restoration, all
adjustments in connection with publicly or privately owned public utilities and
all other adjustments made necessary by the construction, maintenance,
operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of any special street
privilege shall be paid by the permittee, unless otherwise provided.
   (b)   All such streets and sidewalk restoration and other necessary work of
adjustment shall be performed in accordance with the specifications on hand at
the Building Department and the provisions of the ordinances or, in the absence
of regulation by ordinance, shall, at the option of the City be performed by
the permittee or by the City at the permittee's expense, unless otherwise
provided.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.12 TERMINATION OF SPECIAL STREET PRIVILEGE.
   (a)   When a special street privilege shall terminate, whether by force of
law, by action of the authorized City authorities, or by reason of abandonment
of the permitted use, the permittee shall immediately remove all private
construction from the street area and make all necessary street and sidewalk
restoration, under the supervision and subject to the approval of the City. In
case of failure to remove and restore within a reasonable time, the City shall
be authorized to make the necessary removal and restoration, and charge the
expense thereof to the permittee, unless otherwise provided.
   (b)   In the case of underground pipes or similar underground construction,
where the pipes or other equipment can be effectively sealed, and the existence
of the private construction in the street, alley or way presents, in the sole
opinion of the City, no difficulties, the City may waive the removal and
instead authorize the necessary sealing. All pipes or equipment left in any
street, alley or way shall thereupon become the property of the City.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.13 LIABILITY OF PERMITTEE.
   It shall be a condition of the use or enjoyment of any special street
privilege that the permittee shall save and hold the City harmless of any and
all liability, claims or expenses of any kind caused by, or growing out of, the
construction, maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment
of such special street privilege. Whenever, in the sole opinion of the City,
the construction or maintenance of a structure within a street privilege area
is attended with the possibility of substantial damage or loss to the city, to
other property owners, or to members of the public, the City shall be
authorized to require a reasonable bond to protect against such damage or loss.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.14 REVOCABILITY.
   Every special street privilege shall be subject to revocation by the
adoption of an ordinance to revoke by City Council, by the specific terms of
the ordinance which granted the privilege or as provided by this Chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.15 NOTICE.
   Notice from the City or any of its officers of the provisions of this
chapter or of any special street privilege ordinance shall be valid if served
on the permittee or any local agent of the permittee either personally, by mail
addressed to the last known place of residence or by publication in the manner
required for ordinances of the Norwood Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.16 UNLAWFUL PRIVATE USE OF STREETS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or maintain a private use of
a public street, alley or way, other than an authorized building encroachment,
except in accordance with an ordinance authorizing such use, and in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.17 SECRET STREET USES.
   No person, firm or corporation shall knowingly install or cause to be
installed, or shall knowingly maintain or operate, or cause to be maintained or
operated, in any public street, alley or way, an underground pipe, conduit or
other underground street use without authority granted in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.18 DISCOVERY OF UNLAWFUL USES.
   (a)   Whenever the existence of an unlawful street use in violation of this
Chapter herein shall be brought to the attention of the City, the Service
Director shall order such use to be discontinued within 30 days, unless during
such period proper application shall be made in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter for a special street privilege and the sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) shall be paid to the City Treasurer as compensation for the
previous unlawful use; provided that, if the City shall be of the opinion that
the value of the use to the person, firm or corporation unlawfully making such
private use is greater than one hundred dollars ($100.00) over the period in
which the use has existed, or during the period of the preceding five years if
the length of the period cannot be determined, the application shall be
required to pay a sum in addition to the one hundred dollars ($100.00) payment
sufficient to pay the reasonable value of the secret use.
   (b)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to relieve any person from
prosecution or penalty in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.19 CONTROL BY BUILDING COMMISSIONER OR SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   Except as otherwise provided by ordinance, the Building Commissioner or
Service Director shall have full control of the supervision, inspection and
regulation of revocable street privileges. When the public safety or the public
welfare shall require the temporary or permanent discontinuance or modification
of a special street privilege, the Building Commissioner or Service Director
shall take all action necessary for the public interest. If action by Council
is required, the Building Commissioner or Service Director shall advise Council
and cause the necessary legislation to be prepared. The Building Commissioner
or Service Director shall be authorized to prepare and enforce reasonable rules
and regulations to govern the carrying out of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.20 FENCES.
   No person, firm or corporation shall construct or maintain a fence on a City
street, alley or way, without having first applied for permission from the
Service Director who shall cause an investigation to be made, and after such
investigation, shall either approve or deny such application; provided,
however, that if such fence would affect the public's use of a street, alley or
way, said fence shall require approval by a revocable street privilege pursuant
to this Chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.21 WATER METERS AND PITS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall construct or maintain a water meter and
pit on a City street, alley or way without having first applied for permission
from the Service Director who shall cause an investigation to be made, and
after such investigation, shall either approve or deny such application;
provided, however, that if such water meter and pit would effect the public's
use of a street, alley or way, said water meter and pit shall require approval
by a revocable street privilege pursuant to this Chapter.
(Ord. 95-2000. Passed 12-26-00.)
917.22 PENALTIES.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no specific penalty
is described, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor for each separate offense.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
917.23 VIOLATION OF SECTION
917.16.
   Whoever violates any provision of Section
917.16 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Each day’s
unlawful use shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
917.24 VIOLATION OF SECTION
917.17.
   Whoever violates any provision of Section
917.17 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Each day’s
unlawful use shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
917.25 PORTABLE STORAGE CONTAINER.
   (a)   For the purpose of this section, “portable storage container” shall
mean an enclosed unit designed for temporary storage and which can be
transported by vehicle and left on-site.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a portable
storage container on public streets, sidewalks, or public rights of way within
the City limits for three consecutive days in a continuous 180-day period.
   (c)   Following a state, local or federally declared natural disaster or
state of emergency for the City, portable storage containers may be permitted
on public streets, sidewalks or public rights of way. Owners or renters of such
storage containers shall apply for a period required in Section
917.25(d)(2). Such permit shall grant additional time required by the applicant
due to the circumstances resulting from the aforementioned natural disaster or
state of emergency. In no event shall such additional time exceed the time
limitations provided in Section
917.25(d). All portable storage containers placed or maintained pursuant to
this section shall comply with the requirements of Section
917.25(d)(3) and (4).
   (d)   Portable storage containers located outside of a fully-enclosed
building or structure shall be allowed on private property subject to the
following restrictions:
      (1)   A maximum of two portable storage containers may be allowed on a
lot for a period no longer than fifteen days in any consecutive twelve-month
period. A maximum of one portable storage container may be allowed on a lot for
a period no longer than thirty days in any consecutive twelve month period. In
any case where there is a change in ownership of the lot, the date upon which
title to the lot is conveyed shall begin a new twelve month period. The
portable storage container must be placed a minimum of five feet from the
property line and must be sited on an asphalt, concrete, gravel or hard paved
surface or on the driveway of the lot. No portable storage container shall have
dimensions greater than twelve feet in length, eight feet in width, or eight
feet in height.
      (2)   A permit issued by the Safety-Service Director is required for any
portable storage container located on a lot for more than thirty consecutive
days. Such permit shall allow the portable storage container to remain on a lot
for a period no greater than an additional fifteen consecutive days. Such
container shall comply with the siting requirements of Section
917.25(d)(1). The fee for such permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
The permit shall be displayed on the exterior of the portable storage unit at
all times.
      (3)   Other than the required City permit, no sign shall be attached to a
portable storage container except as authorized by the regulations set forth
within Chapter
1321 “Signs” of the Building Code.
      (4)   All portable storage containers shall be maintained in a condition
free from rust, peeling paint, graffiti, and other visible forms of
deterioration.
   (e)   This section shall not apply to portable storage containers located on
private property properly zoned and approved by the City for the outdoor
storage of portable storage containers.
   (f)   This section shall be enforceable by the Building Commissioner and his
agents or designees and officers of the Norwood Police Department.
   (g)   Nothing in this section shall override the ability or authority of the
Safety-Service Director to maintain the public streets, sidewalks, or public
rights of way within the City limits as provided in these Codified Ordinances
and to provide for the health, safety, and welfare of the City as it relates to
the same.
   (h)   Whoever violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor. An offender who, within one year of the offense, previously
has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of this section or any
other substantially similar state statute or municipal ordinance, is guilty of
a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Each day that the unlawful use of outdoor
storage container(s) continues shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 67-2008. Passed 11-25-08.)

Rights of Way
