925.01 ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION; PURPOSE.
   From and after the enactment or passage of this section the Director of
Public Service, for the purpose of paying the expenses of conducting the
Waterworks/Water Department of the City, shall assess and collect a water rent
or charge of sufficient amount and in such manner as he determines to be most
equitable from tenements and premises supplied with water or individuals or
entities of every kind and description who use water within the City.
(Ord. 20-1992. Passed 8-11-92.)
925.02 LEVY; AMOUNT.
   The Director of Public Service shall levy and assess charges in a sufficient
amount to pay the current operating expenses and costs of permanent
improvements to the City waterworks or water system on an annual basis.
(Ord. 20-1992. Passed 8-11-92.)
925.03 COUNCIL NOTIFIED OF INCREASE.
   The Director of Public Service shall notify Council in written form of every
increase in water charges or assessments at least thirty days prior to the
implementation of same.
(Ord. 20-1992. Passed 8-11-92.)
925.04 DIRECTOR TO ESTABLISH BILLING, FEES, DEPOSITS, ETC.
   The Director of Public Service shall establish billing cycles, minimum
charges based on size of meters, cubic foot rates and minimum charges, fees for
delinquent payments, liability for water charges, deposits for service, charges
for fire service branches, seal charges or any other service incidental to the
operation of the City Waterworks/Water Department necessary for the operation
of such Department.
(Ord. 20-1992. Passed 8-11-92.)
925.05 REPEAL OF FORMER SECTIONS.
   Former Sections
925.01 through and including 925.12 of the City Codified Ordinances are
repealed effective sixty days from the passage of this section or the
establishment of rents and charges for water within the City by the Director of
Public Service.
(Ord. 20-1992. Passed 8-11-92.)
925.06 COLLECTION.
   When water rents or charges are not paid when due, the Director of Public
Service may do either or both of the following:
   (a)   Certify them, together with any penalties, to the County Auditor. The
County Auditor shall place the certified amount on the real property tax list
and duplicate against the property served by the connection if he also receives
from the Director of Public Service additional certification that the unpaid
rents or charges have arisen pursuant to a service contract made directly with
an owner who occupies the property served.
   (b)   Collect them by actions at law, in the name of the City from an owner,
tenant or other person who is liable to pay the rents or charges.
      (Ord. 4-1998. Passed 1-13-98.)
925.07 RATES AND BILLING PROCEDURES.
   (a)   Cubic Foot Rates. The minimum charge for water services supplied by
the City within the City limits shall be for 0 - 1000 cubic feet per quarter or
0 - 300 cubic feet per month. Each 100 cubic feet after the minimum will be
billed according to Ordinance No. 20-1992.
   (b)   Payment; Computation. When there is a rate increase, quarterly bills
shall be equitably calculated on the basis of two-thirds at the old rates and
one-third at the new rates; next quarterly bills shall be calculated at two-
thirds new rates, one-third old rates. Quarterly bills thereafter shall be
calculated at the new rates. Monthly bills shall be billed at the new rates.
   (c)   Minimum Charges. Minimum charges for water service supplied by the
City within the City limits shall be based on the size of the meter used:
Meter Size (Inches)
5/8
3/4
1 and 1 1/4
1 ½
2
3
4
6
8
10
12
   (d)   Billing; Payment. Water bills shall ordinarily be payable at intervals
of three months, but the Director of Public Service shall be authorized to
provide, in special cases or in certain classes of accounts, for payment for
shorter intervals. Water bills shall be paid on or before the dates stated on
the bill. The Director may grant an extension of time for payment not to exceed
forty-five days from the due date without penalty in cases of indigency, relief
and similar conditions after investigation. Partial payments may be accepted
but bills shall be paid in full before the expiration of the forty-five day
period.
   (e)   Delinquent Payments. When a water bill has not been paid by the date
stated on the original bill, a delinquent notice shall be sent adding a penalty
of ten percent (10%) to the water charge. If payment is not made, a shut off
bill shall be prepared. If the same is not paid within the time stated on the
bill, a shut off notice will be delivered to the address with an additional fee
set by the Director of Service. If the bill is not paid in full at City Hall on
or before the shut off date, water shall be shut off immediately with the
additional shut off fee set by the Director of Service and added to the bill.
It shall not be turned on again until all charges due and payable including
advance charges, if any, are fully paid. This section shall apply whether or
not there has been in the meantime a change of ownership or possession of the
premises supplied.
   (f)   Owner’s Liability for Charges. Any owner of real estate premises
installing or maintaining water service connections shall be considered as
accepting the provisions of all lawful rules and regulations of the Water
Department and as agreeing, in particular, to be liable for all water and
service charges for such premises whether the accounts for such premises are
carried in the name of tenants or other persons.
   (g)   Fire Services Branches for Private Premises; Charges. A quarterly
charge shall be made for each fire service branch servicing private premises
within or outside of the City, based on the size at the main. These charges
shall apply in all cases where water is available at the intake cock. There
shall be no charge for water used from a fire service branch for fire
protection.
   (h)   Seal; Charges. When a fire service branch has outlets, such as fire
hydrants or fire hose outlets, not on an alarm system, the outlet shall be
sealed. The seal shall not be broken except when necessary for fire protection,
fire prevention or firefighting purposes. When such a seal is found to have
been broken, otherwise than for any fire protection, fire prevention or
firefighting purpose, a charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be made
for resealing, and such charge shall be collected by the Water Department by
placing same on the regular water bills.
   (i)   Water Service Deposit. A deposit for water service shall be required
from owners of restaurants, laundromats, car washes, and other businesses and
residences.
   (j)   Service Charges. The following rates for isolated water use shall be
as follows:
      (1)   Frozen or damaged meter.
 
Meter Size (Inches)
5/8                 $70.00
3/4                 105.00
1                   125.00
   (k)   Payments Required for Service Initiation or Repair. The charges
contained in subsections (i) and (j) shall be paid prior to the initiation and/
or repair of any water service.
(Ord. 4-1999. Passed 1-12-99.)
CHAPTER 929
Water Meters
929.01   Installation, replacement, repair and maintenance.
929.02   Size determines maintenance responsibility.
929.03   Location.
929.04   Sealing and noncompliance fee.
929.05   Unlawful removal; water turn on fee.
929.06   Right of entry.
929.07   Fire service detector check meter.
929.08   Testing fees; exceptions.
929.09   Electronic meter reading systems.
929.10   Meter testing.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Tampering with water hydrants, pipes or meters; unauthorized connection - see
Ohio R. C. 4933.22; GEN. OFF.
541.04 
Water charges - see S. U. & P. S. Ch.
925
Water connections - see S. U. & P. S. Ch.
931
 
929.01 INSTALLATION, REPLACEMENT, REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE.
   The original purchase and installation of a water meter shall be made by the
consumer. After a meter has been installed and placed in service, the City
Water Department will assume the maintenance of the meter or its replacement by
another meter of the same size, without charge to the consumer. Therefore, the
meter becomes City property, provided, however, that in the case of damage by
freezing, hot water or other neglect on the part of the consumer, the cost of
repairs or of replacement shall be charged to the consumer. If these costs are
not paid within thirty days, the Water Department shall discontinue service
until such charges are paid.
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82. )
929.02 SIZE DETERMINES MAINTENANCE RESPONSIBILITY.
   Section
929.01 shall apply only in those cases where five-eighths inch, three-fourths
inch or one inch meters are installed. All water meters more than one inch size
shall be installed, replaced, repaired and maintained by the consumer. The
replacements or repairs shall be made within thirty days after notification by
the Water Department. If repairs or replacement is not made, the water shall be
shut-off at the curb.
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82.)
929.03 LOCATION.
   Meters shall be firmly and substantially set in a workmanlike manner in a
convenient location readily accessible for reading and examination, and shall
be protected from frost
or other injury.
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82.)
929.04 SEALING AND NONCOMPLIANCE FEE.
   (a)    The Water Department shall seal all water meters. The seal shall not
be broken except by authorized personnel of the Department, or for emergency
repairs. The Department shall be notified prior to the breaking of the meter
seal. If emergency repairs are necessary during nonworking hours, notification
shall be made on the next working day.
   (b)    Any noncompliance with the above procedure shall be deemed a
violation and shall be subject to an administrative fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) payable within thirty days of notice of noncompliance. If not paid
within such time period, water service shall be discontinued until payment is
received.
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82.)
929.05 UNLAWFUL REMOVAL; WATER TURN ON FEE.
   No person other than an authorized employee of the Water Department shall
remove a meter without permission of the Director of Public Service. When a
meter has been unlawfully removed, it shall be unlawful to use water supplied
by the service branch to which the meter was attached. Where a meter is found
to have been unlawfully removed, the water shall be shut-off forthwith and not
turned on again until payment has been made for the estimated amount of the
water used, plus the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82.)
929.06 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   Authorized employees of the Water Department shall have the right, at any
reasonable time, to enter any premises where a meter is installed, for the
purpose of reading, examining or testing the same on the premises, or for the
purpose of removing the same from the premises for examination, test, repair or
replacement. Should authorized City employees be denied entrance to such
property after providing notice to property owner, the Water Department shall
have the right to shut water off at the curb.
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82.)
929.07 FIRE SERVICE DETECTOR CHECK METER.
   All fire service branches installed after the effective date of this section
shall require a detector check meter.
(Ord. 25-1982. Passed 6-22-82).
929.08 TESTING FEES; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)    After the effective date of this section, the consumer shall be
responsible to the City for the testing of any water meter within the City.
   (b)    Subsection (a) hereof shall not apply to any consumer whose water
meter is not found to be within the test limits as established by the American
Water Works Association.
   (c)    The fee for testing water meters shall be ten dollars ($10.00).
   (d)    Any increase or decrease in the cost to the City for testing water
meters shall be reflected by a direct increase or decrease in the charge to the
consumer.
(Ord. 18-1983. Passed 2-8-83.)
929.09 ELECTRONIC METER READING SYSTEMS.
   All new or replacement meters are to be standardized to a Neptune Company
meter equipped with an Electronic Reading System with direct reading remote
touch-pad. All new meters must be of the 6 gear register type for future hook
up to a phone or radio system. This will permit the reading of the consumer’s
water meter without entering the building in which the meter is located. The
location of the Electronic Meter Reading System shall be subject to the
approval of the Water Department in order to insure safe and reasonable access
for verification of readings or for maintenance.
(Ord. 80-1997. Passed 12-23-97.)
929.10 METER TESTING.
   Meters shall be tested by the Water Department or its designee at five year
intervals.
(Ord. 80-1997. Passed 12-23-97.)

931.01   Connection to pipes or fire hydrants: permit required.

931.01 CONNECTION TO PIPES OR FIRE HYDRANTS: PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person either as principal or agent or otherwise, shall tap, or connect
with any of the water pipes, hydrants or fire plugs, belonging to or managed or
controlled by the City, including any fire hydrant or fire plug and the pipe
supplying the same wherever located on private or public property in the City,
or draw or use any water from any of the water pipes, hydrants or fire plugs,
unless a written permit has first been obtained from the Director of Public
Service; and in case of tapping, or connecting with, or of drawing or using
water from, any fire hydrant or fire plug, unless a written permit has also
been obtained from the Chief of the Fire Department. No person shall tap or
connect with or draw or use any water from any other water pipe, hydrant or
fire plug except such as may be specified in the permit herein provided for. No
person shall tap, or connect with or draw or use water from any such water
pipes, hydrants or fire plugs except during the time specified in the permit.
(Ord. 1688-1904. Passed 5-2-04.)
931.02 PERMIT FEES.
   For every permit required by Section
931.01 there shall be paid into the Water Fund the water rent or other charge
fixed by the Director of Public Service, and for every permit to tap, connect
with or use water from any fire hydrant or fire plug, there shall be paid into
the Water Fund the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) provided that the Fire
Department may use fire plugs and fire hydrants in the line of its duties
without any permit. It shall also be lawful for the Director of Public Works
after notifying the Chief of the Fire Department in writing, to tap or connect
with such fire hydrants or plugs without payment of fees for any lawful
purposes of the Department of Public Service, and such notices from the
Director of Public Works or his designated agent shall be in such form that the
Chief of the Fire Department may keep a record and file of the notices.
(Ord. 1688-1904. Passed 5-2-04.)
931.03 TAMPERING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall molest, tamper with, deface or otherwise in any manner
injure any property or apparatus belonging to the Department of Public Works or
any other department of the City.
(Ord. 1688-1904. Passed 5-2-04.)
931.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 933

933.01   Permit required.
933.02   Permits granted; nonliability of City.
933.03   Master plumbers license required.
933.04   License fee; bond.
933.05   Maintenance; acceptance.

933.09   Charges.

CROSS REFERENCES

933.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.   \
   No connection shall be made with any public sewer or drain within the City,
without the written permission of the City, to be granted by the Director of
Public Service, and every connection or opening made into any public sewer or
drain without such permission, or in any manner different from the manner
prescribed in this chapter for such opening or connection, shall subject the
persons making the same and the owner or owners of the premises directing, to a
penalty hereinafter prescribed. Each day that any person shall, without such
permission, continue to use the drain into the sewers, shall be considered a
separate offense.
(Ord. 646-1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.02 PERMITS GRANTED; NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   The Director of Public Service is hereby authorized to grant such permits as
he may deem necessary for allowing persons to tap the public sewers or drains,
and to make connections therewith. However, all permits shall be granted on the
express conditions that the owner and tenant, for whose benefit the connections
are made, shall, in consideration of the privilege thereby granted, hold the
City harmless for any loss or damage that may in any way result or be
occasioned by such tap or connection. (Ord. 646-1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.03 MASTER PLUMBERS LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall make any connection with or opening into any sewer or drain
unless he has been licensed as a master plumber by the City and has obtained
the license required under Section
933.04.
933.04 LICENSE FEE; BOND.
   (a)   All licenses to tap or make sewer connections in the City shall be
issued by the Director of Public Service, and shall be in force for one year
from the date of issue, unless sooner revoked. A fee of two dollars ($2.00)
shall be charged for each license issued, to be paid into the City treasury to
the credit of the General Fund.
   (b)   Every person to whom a license is granted, shall at the time the
license is received, file a bond, approved by the Director of Public Service,
in the sum of five hundred dollars, ($500.00), conditioned to indemnify and
save it harmless from all damages which may arise from making connections with
the public sewers of the City. No person so licensed shall make any extra
charge for work done on account of a license being granted.
(Ord. 646-1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.05 MAINTENANCE; ACCEPTANCE.
   Whoever is licensed, and makes any connection with any sewer or drain, shall
keep in repair and good order the whole work executed by him, until the same is
accepted by the Director of Public Service, whose acceptance shall be in
writing and shall not be given until at least three months after the completion
of the work. Such acceptance shall not obligate the City to keep such sewer in
repair at the City's cost.
(Ord. 646-1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.06 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   All applications for permits must be in writing upon blanks furnished by the
Director of Public Service, signed by the owners and tenants of the premises,
for whose benefit it is made, or by his or their authorized agents or attorneys
and must state the number of the lot, number of feet front, name, number or
letter of the sewer district in which the premises are located, the name of the
owner, and the number and character of the buildings to be connected and how
occupied, the number of drains required and the water closets, sinks and other
fixtures to be connected with the same. The applications shall be filed in the
office of the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 646- 1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.07 SUPERVISION; CHARGES.
   All connections made with public sewers shall be under the direction and
supervision of the Director of Public Service, or other person authorized for
that purpose. The expenses of such supervision shall be paid by the applicant.
(Ord. 646-1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.08 VIOLATIONS.
   (a)    Any person licensed to make connections with the public sewers in the
City, who violates any provision of this chapter, shall be fined according to
Section
933.99 hereof and their license shall be revoked.
 
   (b)    Whoever makes or permits to be made, on or adjoining his premises,
any connection with any public sewer in the City, except in manner and form as
prescribed in this chapter, or whoever makes or attempts to make, any sewer
connection without being licensed, shall be fined according to Section
933.99.
 
   (c)    Each day intervening between the making of a connection with any
public sewer and compliance with any of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a
separate offense, and punished accordingly.
 
   (d)    No owner, or any person in possession of premises into which a pipe
or other connection with the public sewers or drains has been laid for the
purpose of carrying off excrement from privies or water closets, slops from the
kitchens or for other purposes shall allow the same to remain without good and
perfect fixtures or without fixtures for supplying water and the proper
connections thereto, and whoever fails or neglects to provide the fixtures
shall be fined according to Section
933.99.
 
   (e)    Whoever throws or deposits any butcher's offal, garbage, stone, wood,
straw, rags or any other article or obstruction of any kind into any basin,
tank, manhole, sewer, ditch or drain in the City, or breaks, injures, removes
or in any manner interferes with any tank, catch basin, manhole cover or any
part of any sewer or its appurtenances, or obstructs in any manner any inlet or
outlet of any sewer or drain shall be fined according to Section
933.99.
 
   (f)   The Director of Public Service shall forthwith file complaint with the
Mayor against any person who has, to his knowledge, been probably guilty of a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. Failure to do so shall
subject him to removal from office.
 
   (g)    The Mayor shall have no power to either remit or suspend any of the
penalties herein prescribed.
(Ord. 646-1894. Passed 1-29-94.)
933.09 CHARGES.
   (a)    The charges for sewage services as fixed by the Metropolitan Sewer
District shall be made by the Department of Public Works. These charges shall
be included upon all water bills mailed by and payable to the City.
(Ord. 34-1948. Passed 6-22-48.)
   (b)    Sewerage service charges shall be payable at the office of the
Department of Public Works at the same time as the water bills for the lot,
parcel of land, building or premises are payable, and payments for water shall
not be accepted unless payment of the sewerage service charge is made at the
same time.
   Charges to users for special equipment, materials and services may be
payable in the same way as sewerage service charges.
(Ord. 28-1962. Passed 4-24-62.)
933.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 937
Sewerage and Drainage Obstructions
937.01   Permit for watercourse obstruction.
937.02   Notice to remove drainage obstructions; noncompliance.
937.03   Elimination of obstructions by City; owner liable.
937.04   Land fill permit; fee; modification deposit.
937.05   Alteration of watercourse; permit; fee.
937.06   Inspection.
937.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Interference with sewage flow - see Ohio R. C. 4933.24
Notice to fill lots, remove putrid substances - see GEN. OFF.
521.05
Obstructing sewers - see S.U. & P. S.
933.08
 
937.01 PERMIT FOR WATERCOURSE OBSTRUCTION.
   Anyone owning or having the possession, charge or management of any lot,
parcel or real estate over which any watercourse, drain or sewer passes shall
not cause or permit such watercourse, drain or sewer to be obstructed,
diverted, culverted or enclosed without a permit from the Director of Public
Service.
(Ord. 51-1967. Passed 9-12-67.)
937.02 NOTICE TO REMOVE DRAINAGE OBSTRUCTIONS; NONCOMPLIANCE.
   Whenever the Director of Public Service finds that, by reason of making a
diversion, culvert, enclosure, fill or partial fill thereon, a tract of land is
inadequately drained or that such diversion, culvert, enclosure, fill or
partial fill obstructs or interferes with lawfully existing sewerage or
drainage he shall notify the person owning or having the possession, charge or
management of such lot or parcel of real estate to remove the fill or to
provide the necessary sewerage to adequately serve the drainage area. The
notice may be served upon such person by personal delivery, by mail at his last
known place of residence or by posting it on the premises. Failure, after
service of the notice, to remove the fill or to provide the necessary sewerage
shall constitute an unlawful act if continued for a period of ten days. Each
additional period of ten days thereafter during which the owner fails to carry
out the order of the Director shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 51-1967. Passed 9-12-67.)
 
937.03 ELIMINATION OF OBSTRUCTIONS BY CITY; OWNER LIABLE.
   In case of an emergency or in any case where an obstruction caused by a
diversion, culvert, enclosure, fill or partial fill has continued for more than
thirty days after the serving of notice in accordance with Section
937.02, the Director of Public Service shall be authorized to cause any
necessary measures to be taken to protect existing drainage systems and to
charge the expense thereof to the owner of the property on which the
obstruction was made. This section shall not be construed to relieve the owner
of any penalties prescribed by other sections of this chapter.
(Ord. 51-1967. Passed 9-12-67.)
937.04  LAND FILL PERMIT; FEE; MODIFICATION DEPOSIT.
   (a)   Anyone owning or having the possession, charge or management of any
lot or parcel of real estate on which a fill or partial fill is to be made,
shall, before making such fill, apply to the Director of Public Service for a
permit authorizing the same to be made, stating in his application the location
of the tract and the nature and the dimensions of the fill proposed. If the
Director is satisfied that the proposed fill will not interfere with adequate
drainage for the area and will not obstruct, damage or interfere with lawfully
existing sewerage or drainage, public or private, or cause a stagnant pond of
water to form, he shall issue a permit authorizing the fill. The permit fee
shall be ten dollars ($10.00).
   (b)   In the event it becomes necessary to adjust, relocate or otherwise
modify the existing sewer systems including any appurtenances, as a result of
placing the fill, the applicant authorized to make the fill shall, at his
expense, make such adjustments, relocations or modifications, as required by
the Director before or during the filling operation.
   (c)    A deposit shall be made by the applicant making the fill, with the
City Treasurer, covering the estimated cost of the work. If the applicant
authorized to make the fill fails to make the required changes as specified,
the Director shall cause the work to be done by City forces, charging the
expense against the deposit. The deposit or unused portion of the deposit shall
be refunded when all work is accepted by the City.
   (d)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the filling of
abandoned cellars, cisterns or other cavities not involving sewerage or
drainage.
937.05  ALTERATION OF WATERCOURSE; PERMIT; FEE.
   Anyone owning or having the possession, charge or management of any lot or
parcel of real estate over which any natural watercourse passes shall not cause
or permit such natural watercourse to be diverted, culverted or otherwise
enclosed or artificially confined until they have submitted the detail plans
for the diversion, culvert, walls or other enclosing or confining structure to
the City Engineer, and have obtained his approval thereof; nor until they have
obtained a permit from the Director of Public Service for the diverting,
culverting or otherwise enclosing of the natural watercourse, provided always
that neither the approval of such plans nor the issuance of such permit shall
be construed as a guarantee on the part of the City as to the sufficiency of
such structure or diversion ditch. The permit fee shall be five dollars
($5.00).
(Ord. 51-1967. Passed 9-12-67.)
937.06 INSPECTION.
   All construction performed under Sections
937.04 and
937.05, shall be subject to inspection and approval by the Director of Public
Service. The contractor shall notify the Director at least twelve hours before
the work is ready for inspection. Sewers, culverts, walls or other enclosing or
confining structures shall be kept uncovered, free and clear until they are
inspected and approved. All work shall be subject to final inspection upon
completion.
(Ord. 51-1967. Passed 9-12-67.)
937.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)

CHAPTER 953
Municipal Refuse Collection
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance 14-1993, passed April 13, 1993, approves the Solid
Waste Management Plan of the Hamilton County Solid Waste Management District.
953.01   Definitions.
953.02   Collection by City.
953.03   Collection supervised by Director.
953.04   Refuse containers.
953.05   Collection practices.
953.06   Fee for refuse disposal.
953.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES

Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et seq.
Illegal deposits of garbage, refuse - see GEN. OFF.

Rat control - see HLTH.

953.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
   (a)   "Ashes" means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or
other combustible materials.
   (b)   "City" means the City of Norwood.
   (c)   "Commercial or industrial garbage or waste" means all industrial
garbage or waste capable of incineration or burning that accumulates in, upon
or about the land and buildings appurtenant to the business and activities of
breweries, wholesale produce and grocery dealers, restaurants and hotels, meat
packing and meat wholesale dealers, and fat rendering and hide processing
plants.
   (d)   "Container service" means the private hauling of garbage from
businesses or multi- family units that contain five (5) or more dwelling units.
   (e)   "Director" means the Director of Public Service.
   (f)   "Family" means the persons occupying an individual unit.
   (g)   "Garbage" means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from
the handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food.
   (h)   "Householder" means the head of a family or one maintaining his or her
separate living room or quarters in the City.
   (i)   "Individual special service" means collection service to persons who
desire collection from their premises at locations other than the line of the
public street, alley or service strip along the collection route.
   (j)   "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (k)   "Refuse" means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except
body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead
animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes.
   (l)   "Rubbish" means nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes),
consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper,
cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar
materials.
   (m)   "Subscriber" means any householder within the City of Norwood, Ohio.
   (n)   "Unit/Commercial" means any individual business within the corporate
limits of the City occupied as a business. A unit shall be deemed occupied when
either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto.
   (o)   "Unit/Residence" means each single-family dwelling or individual
apartment within a dwelling within the corporate limits of the City occupied by
a householder. A unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic
light and power services are being supplied thereto.
(Ord. 22-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
953.02  COLLECTION BY CITY.
   All refuse accumulated in the City shall be collected, conveyed, and
disposed of as set by ordinance of the City. No person shall collect, convey
over any of the streets or alleys of the City, or dispose of any refuse
accumulated in the City unless authorized by the City.
   (a)    Exception for Actual Producers. This chapter shall not prohibit the
actual producers of refuse, or the owners of premises upon which refuse has
accumulated, from personally collecting, conveying and disposing of such
refuse, provided such producers or owners comply with the provisions of this
chapter and with any other governing law or ordinances.
   (b)   Exception for Outside Collectors. This chapter shall not prohibit
collectors of refuse from outside of the City when collecting and hauling such
refuse from traveling over City streets, provided such collectors comply with
the provisions of this chapter and with any other governing law or ordinances.
      (Ord. 22-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
953.03 COLLECTION SUPERVISED BY DIRECTOR.
   (a)    All refuse accumulated in the City shall be collected, conveyed and
disposed of as outlined by separate ordinance under the supervision of the
Director. The Director shall have the authority to make regulations concerning
the days of collection, type and location of waste containers and such other
matters pertaining to the collection of refuse and disposal thereof as he shall
find necessary and to change and modify the same after notice as required by
law, provided that such regulations are not contrary to the provisions hereof.
The Director shall review and permit container service for commercial or
residential buildings exceeding three (3) units as the Director deems
appropriate, subject to the laws and ordinances of the City.
   (b)    Appeals. Any person aggrieved by a regulation of or fee charged by
the Director shall have the right of appeal to the Director, who s-all have the
authority to confirm, modify or revoke any such regulation or fee.
(Ord. 22-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
953.04 REFUSE CONTAINERS.
   (a)    Duty to Provide and Maintain in Sanitary Condition. Refuse containers
shall be provided by the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of the premises.
Refuse containers shall be maintained in good condition. Any container that
does not conform to the provisions of this chapter or that may have ragged or
sharp edges or any other defect that is likely to hamper or injure the person
collecting the contents thereof shall be promptly replaced upon notice. The
Director shall have the authority to refuse collection services for failure to
comply herewith.
   (b)    Storing of Refuse.
      (1)   Public places. No person shall place any refuse in any street,
alley or other public place, or upon any private property, whether owned by
such person or not, within the City unless it is in proper containers for
collection or under express approval granted by the Director; nor shall any
person throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or other body of water.
      (2)    Unauthorized accumulation. Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse
on any premises is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and is prohibited.
   (c)    Dumpster. Property containing four or more units may utilize a single
dumpster for the removal of refuse provided its location meets all zoning,
health and regulatory codes of the City and appropriate notarized statement is
submitted to the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 22-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
953.05 COLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)    Frequency of Collection.
      (1)    Residential. Refuse accumulated by residences shall be collected
at least once a week.
      (2)   Commercial. Restaurants and such other businesses and institutions
as deem it necessary may enter into an agreement for a greater frequency of
collection. Where necessary to protect the public health, the Director shall
have the authority to require that more frequent collections be made.
   (b)    Limitation on Quantity.
      (1)    Residential. The Director shall collect a reasonable accumulation
of refuse of each unit/residence during the collection period for the standard
charge.
      (2)    Commercial. The Director shall collect a reasonable accumulation
of refuse of each unit/commercial during the collection period.
   (c)    Collection by Actual Producers and Outside Collectors. 
      (1)    Requirements for vehicles. The actual producers of refuse or the
owners of premises upon which refuse is accumulated who desire personally to
collect and dispose of such refuse; persons who desire to dispose of waste
material not included in the definition of refuse; and collectors of refuse
from outside the City who desire to haul over the streets of the City, shall
use a water-tight vehicle provided with a tight cover so operated as to prevent
offensive odors escaping therefrom and refuse from being blown, dropped or
spilled.
      (2)    Rules and regulations. The Director shall have the authority to
make such other reasonable regulations concerning individual collection and
disposal and relating to the collection and hauling of refuse over City streets
by outside collectors as he shall find necessary.
         (Ord. 22-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
953.06 FEE FOR REFUSE DISPOSAL.
   (a)   The Safety-Service Director, Treasurer and Auditor are hereby
authorized to determine the total cost of garbage disposal, including the
contractual cost of having the service provided, as well as the administrative
costs to the City and divide that amount by the number of residential or
business units producing waste and requiring garbage disposal service as
determined by the parameters of this section and the Norwood Codified
Ordinances. Each individual unit shall then be charged a uniform fee.
   (b)   Apartments or dwellings with multiple residential units shall be
billed a fee, as described in subsection (a) hereof, for each unit within the
apartment or dwelling. Buildings with multiple businesses or residential units
shall be billed a fee for each unit within the building.
   (c)   Businesses without a dumpster pick-up service that meets the
requirements of the Norwood Codified Ordinances shall be billed a fee as
outlined in subsection (a) hereof.
   (d)   The garbage disposal service provided by the City of Norwood is to be
the exclusive method of garbage disposal in the City of Norwood, except as
provided herein and in the Norwood Codified Ordinances. Any violation of these
provisions shall be a minor misdemeanor.
   (e)   The City is hereby authorized to charge a penalty of five percent (5%)
for any fees not paid more than thirty (30) days from the billing date. For
each additional thirty (30) days that such fees remain unpaid, the City is
authorized to charge an additional five percent (5%) penalty.
(Ord. 48-2004. Passed 10-26-04.)
953.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 955
Dumpsters
955.01   Use and approval.
955.02   Compliance with specifications.
955.03   Care and maintenance.
955.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R. C. 715.43, 717.01
Containers, safety standards - see Ohio R.C. 3791.21
Rat control - see HLTH.
1747.13,
1747.14
 
955.01 USE AND APPROVAL.
   (a)    Dumpsters may be used as collection receptacles for refuse and
garbage within the City limits.
   (b)    No person shall hereafter cause a dumpster to be put into use on his
residence, business premises, enterprise or establishment without first
securing approval of the proposed use and specifications from the City Health
Department.
(Ord. 3-1985. Passed 1-8-85.)
955.02  COMPLIANCE WITH SPECIFICATIONS.
   Dumpsters or containers used for the storage of rubbish, garbage, grease and
recyclables shall meet all of the following specifications:
   (a)    Dumpsters shall be watertight.
   (b)    Dumpsters shall be made of a suitable material approved by the City
Health Department.
   (c)    Dumpsters being placed for the first time upon a given premises shall
be new or cleaned thoroughly and in good repair.
   (d)    Dumpsters serving residential dwelling units shall have, as minimum
capacity, six cubic feet of space per dwelling unit served thereby.
      (Ord. 3-1985. Passed 1-8-85.)
   (e)    Dumpsters being placed for the first time upon a given premises shall
be placed upon a concrete slab. Dumpsters that are currently located upon a
blacktop, asphalt or macadam surface are not required to be placed upon a
concrete slab, provided that the blacktop, asphalt or macadam surface
supporting the dumpster is in good condition. However, any dumpster that is
located on a blacktop, asphalt or macadam surface shall be relocated to a
concrete slab at such time as the blacktop, asphalt or macadam surface
supporting the dumpster deteriorates to the point of requiring resurfacing. At
such point, the dumpster shall be placed upon a concrete slab. Such concrete
slab shall be approved by an official of the Building Department.
(Ord. 59-1988. Passed 11-8-88.)
   (f)   Wooden fencing, concrete, block, chain link fence with the metal
slats, or other materials accepted by the Health Commissioner, which are of
sufficient height and width to shield the dumpster from the public view shall
be maintained. Existing dumpsters shall meet the provisions of this subsection
within three years after the effective date of this subsection.
(Ord. 7-1996. Passed 2-13-96.)
   (g)    Dumpsters shall be constructed and maintained with lids and/or doors
which are capable of being completely closed and fastened shut.
   (h)    Except when rubbish and garbage is being loaded into or emptied out
of the dumpster, the lids and doors shall be kept closed and fastened shut with
a latch or similar mechanism.
(Ord. 3-1985. Passed 1-8-85.)
   (i)    Dumpsters serving establishments other than residential dwelling
units shall be kept closed and/or secured, except when rubbish and garbage is
being loaded into or emptied out of the dumpster. Dumpsters serving residential
dwelling units shall not be kept locked unless each tenant is issued a key to
the dumpster.
      (Ord. 70-1997. Passed 9-23-97.)
   (j)    Dumpsters being placed upon streets for the removal of demolition,
building or remodeling debris shall remain upon the street for no more than
five days from date of placement thereon, including Saturdays, Sundays and
holidays. Such dumpsters shall be exempt from the requirements set forth in
subsections (a) through (i) hereof.
   (k)    Dumpsters shall be placed in a location accessible to the pick-up
truck which empties the dumpster, such that the pick-up truck shall not be
forced to drive over any street curb in order to service the dumpster.
(Ord. 3-1985. Passed 1-8-85.)
955.03  CARE AND MAINTENANCE.
   (a)    Dumpsters shall be maintained in good repair and shall be of a size
sufficient to contain the accumulation of trash therein. No garbage or trash
shall be permitted to accumulate in the area surrounding the dumpster.
   (b)    All dumpsters shall be maintained in a reasonably clean manner.
   (c)    It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant, operator or employee of
the residence, business, enterprise or establishment upon whose premises the
dumpster is maintained to insure that the dumpster is emptied on a regular
basis.
   (d)    It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant, operator or employee of
the residence, business, enterprise or establishment upon whose premises the
dumpster is maintained to insure that the dumpster is maintained to establish a
fly and rodent control program as required by the City Board of Health.
(Ord. 3-1985. Passed 1-8-85.)
955.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 3-2004. Passed 1-13-04.)
CHAPTER 959
Alarm Services
959.01   Eligibility.
959.02   Application for termination.
959.03   Fees.
959.04   Equipment and service provided by the Communications Center.
959.05   Equipment and service required of the subscriber.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
False alarms - see GEN. OFF.
509.07
 
959.01  ELIGIBILITY.
   Any financial institution or business establishment that is located within
the geographical boundaries of the City that the Communications Center has the
responsibility of dispatching service and whose application is approved by the
Communications Officer shall be eligible for alarm service termination. The
Communications Officer reserves the right to reject any application for
termination of alarm service.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
959.02 APPLICATION FOR TERMINATION.
   Formal application for each alarm service termination desired at the
Communications or Police Department shall be submitted to the Communications
Officer at the Communications Center, 4725 Montgomery Road, Norwood, Ohio,
45212. Only upon approval of the application and payment of fees, shall the
alarm termination and installation of the lines be permitted.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
959.03 FEES.
   (a)    There shall be a one time installation service fee of one hundred and
thirty dollars ($130.00) for the connection.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
   (b)    An annual monitor fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be
payable in advance with no right of return of any or part of the fee if the
service is terminated by the subscriber during the calendar year. This monitor
fee shall be pro-rated at fifty dollars ($50.00) for each month, including the
month of application remaining in the calendar year for those subscribers
entering the system other than for a full calendar year.
(Ord. 21-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
   (c)    There shall be a false alarm fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per
incident for any false alarm attributed to either defective alarm equipment or
subscriber negligence, after the first false alarm per calendar year. This
section applies to all alarm service provided by alarm companies.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
   (d)    The one time termination fee of one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00)
and the monthly monitor fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each month remaining
in the calendar year including the month of application is due and payable
within ten days of the date the Communications Center gives notice of approval
of the application. Failure to receive the fee within ten days shall constitute
a voluntary withdrawal of the application.
   Succeeding annual billing shall be in July of each year and an annual fee of
six hundred dollars ($600.00) shall be payable within thirty days of the
billing date. Failure to pay within thirty days shall cause an immediate
cancellation of service by the Communications Center. No part of any charge or
fee is returnable if the service is terminated by the subscriber during the
calendar year.
(Ord. 21-1993. Passed 6-22-93.)
   (e)    Direct telephone fees for the Fire-Police Emergency Reporting System
shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month. All connecting fees shall be paid
by the subscriber for the services of the Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company.
Such fees shall be billed each July 1, payable in advance.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
959.04 EQUIPMENT AND SERVICE PROVIDED BY THE COMMUNICATIONS CENTER.
   (a)    The Communications Center reserves the right to terminate alarm
service, for any cause, after thirty days notice to the subscriber. The Center
reserves the right to increase fees after ninety days notice to the subscriber.
   (b)    The Center shall monitor the system and provide immediate response to
an alarm activation as shall be predetermined between the Center and the
subscriber. The Center shall provide maintenance of the City owned annunciator
panel and terminals only. Alarm service termination shall be provided to
approved applicants only on a space - available basis and only on City panels.
When existing terminations are fully occupied, applicants shall be notified,
and may elect to remain on a waiting list until facilities can be provided.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
959.05 EQUIPMENT AND SERVICE REQUIRED OF THE SUBSCRIBER.
   Alarm receiving equipment approved by the Communications Officer compatible
with and capable of proper activation of the City owned annunciator panel,
shall be installed, maintained and interconnected to the City's terminals by
the City at the subscriber’s expense. Responsibility of proper operation,
maintenance and functioning of all equipment, including leased lines and
excluding only the City owned equipment is to be assumed by the subscriber or
the alarm company providing the detecting and receiving equipment and
maintenance service.
(Ord. 40-1981. Passed 8-11-81.)
